tn.text: Jesus and his disciples now walk through a grain field while some Pharisees begin to question the disciples about what they are doing on the Sabbath which, in God's law, has been set aside for God.
The word "you" here is plural, and refers to the disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you can consider using it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
In this case, these are large sections of land where the people had scattered wheat seed to grow more wheat.
This is the topmost part of the grain plant, which is a kind of large grass. It holds the mature, edible seeds of the plant.
They did this to separate the grain seeds. This can be stated clearly. AT: "They rubbed them in their hands to separate the grains from the husks" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Why are you doing something that is not lawful to do on the Sabbath day?
tn.text: They asked this question to accuse the disciples of breaking the law. It can be written as a statement. AT: "Picking grain on the Sabbath is against God's law!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The Pharisees considered even the small action of rubbing a handful of grain to be unlawful work. This can be stated clearly. AT: "doing work" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Have you not even read ... him?
tn.text: Jesus is rebuking the Pharisees for not learning from the scriptures. This can be written as a statement. AT: "You should learn from what you have read ... him" or "Certainly you have read ... him" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"the holy bread" or "the bread that was offered to God"
Jesus was referring to himself. This can be stated: AT: "I, the Son of Man"
The title "Lord" here emphasizes his authority over the Sabbath. AT: "has the authority to determine what is right for people to do on the Sabbath!" (UDB)
The scribes and Pharisees watch as Jesus heals a man on the Sabbath.
It is now another Sabbath day and Jesus is in the synagogue.
This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new event in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
This introduces a new character in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
The man's hand was damaged in such a way that he could not stretch it. It was probably bent into almost a fist, making it look smaller and wrinkled.
"were watching Jesus carefully"
"because they wanted to find"
"in front of everyone" (UDB). Jesus wanted the man to stand where everyone there could see him.
"to the Pharisees"

tn.ref: is it lawful ... save a life ... destroy it?
tn.text: Jesus wanted to correct the Pharisees' understanding that it was wrong to heal on the Sabbath. He asked the question as a contrast between doing good and doing evil in order to make it obvious which one is lawful and which one is wrong. AT: "which action does God's law permit—to do good and heal, or to do harm and destroy a life?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: to do good or to do harm
tn.text: "to help someone or to harm someone"
"Hold out your hand" or "Extend your hand"
"healed"
Jesus chooses twelve apostles after he prays all night.
This phrase is used here to mark the beginning of a new part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
"around that time" or "not long after" or "one day around then"
"Jesus went out"
"When it was morning" or "The next day"
"he chose twelve of the disciples"
"whom he also made apostles" or "and he appointed them to be apostles"

tn.ref: The names of the apostles were
tn.text: This is implied information added to the ULB text. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Simon's brother, Andrew"

Possible meanings are 1) "the Zealot" is a title that indicates he was part of the group of people who wanted to free the Jewish people from Roman rule. AT: "patriot" or "nationalist" or 2) "the zealous one" is a description that indicates he was zealous for God to be honored. AT: "passionate"

It may be necessary to explain what "traitor" means in this context. AT: "betrayed his friend" or "turned his friend over to enemies" (usually in return for money paid) or "exposed a friend to danger by telling enemies about him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Though Jesus especially addresses his disciples, there were many people around who listen.
"with the twelve he had chosen" or "with his twelve apostles"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "for Jesus to heal them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: People who were troubled with unclean spirits were also healed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Jesus also healed people who were troubled with unclean spirits" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"bothered by unclean spirits" or "controlled by evil spirits"

tn.ref: power to heal was coming out from him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "he had power to heal people" or "he used his power to heal people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This phrase is repeated three times. Each time, it indicates that God gives favor to certain people or that their situation is positive or good.

tn.ref: Blessed are you who are poor
tn.text: "You who are poor receive God's favor" or "You who are poor benefit"

tn.ref: for yours is the kingdom of God
tn.text: Languages that do not have a word for kingdom might say, "for God is your king" or "because God is your ruler."

tn.ref: yours is the kingdom of God
tn.text: "the kingdom of God belongs to you." This could mean 1) "you belong to God's kingdom" or 2) "you will have authority in God's kingdom."
"you will laugh with joy" or "you will be joyful"
"You receive God's favor" or "You benefit" or "How good it is for you"
"reject you"

tn.ref: because of the Son of Man
tn.text: "because you associate with the Son of Man" or "because they reject the Son of Man"
"when they do those things" or "when that happens"
This idiom means "be extremely joyful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"a large payment" or "good gifts"

"how terrible it is for you." This phrase is repeated three times. It is the opposite of "blessed are you." Each time, it indicates that God's anger is directed at the people, or that something negative or bad awaits them.

tn.ref: woe to you who are rich
tn.text: "how terrible it is for you who are rich " or "trouble will come to you who are rich"
"what comforts you" or "what satisfies you" or "what makes you happy"
"whose stomachs are full now" or "who eat much now"
"who are happy now"
"How terrible it is for you " or "How sad you should be"
"when all people" or "when everyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: that is how their ancestors treated the false prophets
tn.text: "they also spoke well of the false prophets"
Jesus continues to speak to his disciples and the crowd who is listening to him as well.
Jesus now begins to speak to the entire crowd, rather than just to his disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Each of these commands are to be done continually, not just a single time.
This does not mean they were to only love their enemies and not their friends. This can be stated. AT: "Love your enemies, not only your friends!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
These two phrases mean the same thing, and together emphasize the point. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
God is the one who blesses. This can made explicit. AT: "Ask God to bless those" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"those who habitually curse you"
"those who habitually mistreat you"
"If anyone hits you"
"on one side of your face"
It may be helpful to state what the attacker will do to the person. AT: "turn your face so that he can strike the other cheek also" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"do not prevent him from taking"

tn.ref: Give to everyone who asks you
tn.text: "If anyone asks you for something, give it to him"
"do not require him" or "do not demand"

tn.ref: As you want people to do to you, you should do the same to them
tn.text: In some languages it may be more natural to reverse the order. AT: "You should do to people the same as what you want them to do to you" or "Treat people they way you want them to treat you"

tn.ref: what credit is that to you?
tn.text: "What reward will you receive?" or "What praise will you receive for doing that?" This can be written as a statement. AT: "You will not receive any reward for that" or "God will not reward you for that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: to get back the same amount
tn.text: The law of Moses commanded the Jews not to receive interest on money they loaned to each other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"you will receive a great reward" or "you will receive good payment" or "you will get good gifts because of it"

tn.ref: you will be sons of the Most High
tn.text: It is best to translate "sons" with the same word your language would naturally use to refer to a human son or child.
Make sure that the word "sons" is plural so it is not confused with Jesus' title "The Son of the Most High."
"people who do not thank him and who are evil"
This refers to God. It is best to translate "Father" with the same word your language would naturally use to refer to a human father.
"Do not judge people" or "Do not harshly criticize people" (UDB)
"and as a result you"
Jesus did not say who would not judge. Possible meanings are 1) "God will not judge you" or 2) "no one will judge you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Do not condemn people"
Jesus did not say who would not condemn. Possible meanings are 1) "God will not condemn you" or 2) "no one will condemn you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus did not say who would forgive. Possible meanings are 1) "God will forgive you" or 2) "people will forgive you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: it will be given to you
tn.text: Jesus did not say exactly who would give. Possible meanings are 1) "someone will give it to you" or 2) "God will give it to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

The order of this sentence can be reversed. AT: "They will pour into your lap a generous amount that they have pressed down and shaken together until it is spilling over." Jesus used the metaphor of a grain merchant giving a generous amount. AT: "Like a grain merchant who presses down the grain and shakes it together and pours in so much grain that it spills over, they will give generously to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"A large amount"

tn.ref: it will be measured back to you
tn.text: Jesus did not say exactly who would measure. Possible meanings are 1) "they will measure things back to you" or 2) "God will measure things back to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus includes some examples to make his point. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

tn.ref: Can a blind person guide another blind person?
tn.text: Jesus used this question to get the people to think about something that they already know. This can be written as a statement. AT: "We all know that a blind person cannot guide another blind person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The person who is "blind" is a metaphor for a person who has not been taught as a disciple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Some languages might prefer, "if one did." This is an absurd situation that is not likely to actually happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: they would both fall into a pit, would they not?
tn.text: This can be written as a statement. AT: "both of them would fall into a hole" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: A disciple is not greater than his teacher
tn.text: "A disciple does not surpass his teacher." Possible meanings are 1) "A disciple does not have more knowledge than his teacher" or 2) "A disciple does not have more authority than his teacher."

tn.ref: everyone when he is fully trained
tn.text: "every disciple who has been trained well" or "every disciple whose teacher has fully taught him"

tn.ref: why do you look ... but you do not notice the log that is in your own eye?
tn.text: Jesus uses this question to challenge the people to pay attention to their own sins before they pay attention to another person's sins. AT: "do not look ... but ignore the log that is in your own eye" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the tiny piece of straw that is in your brother's eye
tn.text: This is a metaphor that refers to the less important faults of a fellow believer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"speck" (UDB) or "splinter" or "bit of dust." Use a word for the smallest thing that commonly falls into a person's eyes.
Here "brother" refers to a fellow Jew or a fellow believer in Jesus.

tn.ref: the log that is in your own eye
tn.text: This is a metaphor for a person's most important faults. A log could not literally go into a person's eye. Jesus is emphasizing that a person should pay attention to his own more important faults before he deals with another person's less important faults. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"beam" or "plank"

Jesus asks this question to challenge the people to pay attention to their own sins before they pay attention to another person's sins. AT: "You should not say ... eye" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

People can tell if a tree is good or bad, and what type of tree it is, by the fruit it produces. Jesus uses this as an unexplained metaphor—we know what kind of person someone is when we see their actions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Because there is." This indicates that what follows is the reason why we should not judge our brother.
"healthy tree"
"decaying" or "bad" or "worthless"

People recognize the kind of tree by the fruit it bears. This can be stated in active form. AT: "people know the type of a tree" or "people recognize a tree" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
a plant or shrub that has thorns
a vine or shrub that has thorns

Jesus compares the thoughts of a person to their good or evil treasure. The good thoughts of good people cause good actions. The evil thoughts of evil people cause evil actions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "good" here refers to righteousness or moral goodness.
The word "man" here refers to a person, male or female. AT: "good person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: the good treasure of his heart
tn.text: "the good things he keeps in his heart" or "the good things he values" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Producing what is good is a metaphor for doing what is good. AT: "does what is good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the evil treasure of his heart
tn.text: "the evil things he keeps in his heart" or "the evil things he values" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: out of the abundance of the heart his mouth speaks
tn.text: The phrase "his mouth" represents him using his mouth. AT: "what he thinks in his heart affects what he says with his mouth" or "what he values in his heart determines what he says with his mouth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Jesus compares the person who obeys his teaching to a man who builds a house on rock where it will be safe from floods. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The repetition of these words indicates that they regularly called Jesus "Lord."

tn.ref: Every person who comes to me ... I will tell you what he is like
tn.text: It may be more clear to change the order of this sentence. AT: "I will tell you what every person is like who comes to me and hears my words and obeys them"

tn.ref: built the house's foundation on solid rock
tn.text: "dug the foundation of the house deep enough to reach a foundation of solid rock." Some cultures may not be familiar with building on bedrock, and may need to use another image for a stable foundation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"base" or "support"
"bedrock." This is the very large, hard rock that is deep under the soil.
"fast-moving water" or "river"
"crashed against"
Possible meanings are 1) "cause it to shake" or 2) "destroy it."

tn.ref: because it had been well built
tn.text: "because the man had built it well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus compares the person who hears but does not obey his teaching to a man who builds a house without a foundation so it will collapse in a flood. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"But" shows a strong contrast to the previous person who built with a foundation.

tn.ref: on top of the ground without a foundation
tn.text: Some cultures may not know that a house with a foundation is stronger. Additional information may be helpful. AT: "but he did not dig down and build first a foundation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"base" or "firm support"
"fast-moving water" or "river"
"crashed against"
"fell down" or "came apart"

tn.ref: the ruin of that house was complete
tn.text: "that house was completely destroyed"
